channel.title: Heel Pain
channel.description: So a few days ago I was at the gym playing basketball. Everything was fine until the next day at school. In the morning I was walking fine until it was time to go to English and my heel stared hurting [almost like a smashing feeling]. I thought that it was just regular pain from playing to much, but now it has been 3 days and it's still hurting. This isn't normally what happens. Usually my heels soreness/hurt doesn't come from the middle center of the heel and wont last nearly this long. This is more of a centered pain as opposed to the usual outer-inner soreness. It really hurts when I walk and when waking up in the morning, the first few steps hurt the most. After a while it becomes mild. I'm thinking to go see a doctor but I'm not sure if I should. Any tips on soothing/healing it? Or what it could be?

item.title: Heel Pain
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

The Soul:

I had this same problem after starting back up with football again back in late summer; for me, the pain seemed like it was coming from the bottom of my heel but was actually on the sides / back of it. When I went to the podiatrist, he said it was some disease (I can’t remember the name, it was pretty long); it’s pretty common. The best thing you can do is to get some heel inserts and to try to stay off of your foot as much as you can for a little while until the pain gets better.

I had the exact same problem, and at one point it I did have to purchase heel inserts to stop the pain. I would probably recommend what booknecklad said in order to get the pain to subside and for your heel to heal.

Read full topic

item.title: Heel Pain
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

The central heel pain could be simple bruising from jumping on hard surfaces, but could be a number of other things which would need checking out. The pain first thing in the morning sounds as if plantar faciitis is the most likely cause. You could try using ice packs (or a bottle of frozen water rolled in the arch and heel of the affected foot) for 10 -15 mins per hour. Also take anti inflammatory medicine providing you are able to tolerate it. Finally stretch your calf muscles regularly as this will often help too. If it doesn't start to improve in a week or so with these simple treatments then go and see your doctor and ask to be referred to a Podiatrist or foot specialist.

If you are worried see a doctor sooner.

Read full topic

item.title: Heel Pain
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Probably just from the stress of being an athlete. The extreme would be plantar fasciitis. If you’re really worried go see an orthopedic doctor. But first I’d put some heat on it and let the muscle in your foot relax.

Read full topic
